body:
I think you are right: it should be due to the low light levels => scotopic
vision (option -c in pcond simulate this and it is bundled in the -h
option).
if you want to exclude the -c option, try to use "pcond -a+ -v+ -s+" instead
of "pcond -h+"
cheers,
giulio

-----Original Message-----
[mailto:radiance-general-bounces@radiance-online.org]On Behalf Of John
Sutherland
Sent: 05 April 2004 09:36
To: radiance-general@radiance-online.org

Ok,, my renders internally are doing odd things. The inside of the chapter
house im modelling I would expect to be a little orangey as the textures are
orangy-ish colour. Which is what I get when I do a render then run pcond -s,
its too dark really for an unfiltered render:

https://www.bris.ac.uk/fluff/u/js0754/0j8_md0p1NAu1fdWB6pt8A7o/12hrinternal-
s.jpg
<https://www.bris.ac.uk/fluff/u/js0754/0j8_md0p1NAu1fdWB6pt8A7o/12hrinternal
-s.jpg>

But when I run pcond -h the renders come out very grey, any idea why this
is? Is it correct, is it something to do with the light levels, or contrast
forcing it to grey?

https://www.bris.ac.uk/fluff/u/js0754/2u4diWLd_7Kih_chtUlZTA7o/12hrinternal-
h.jpg
<https://www.bris.ac.uk/fluff/u/js0754/2u4diWLd_7Kih_chtUlZTA7o/12hrinternal

If it is meant to be like this then why? Any ideas

John
